Warren'], 'Studio': ['Gaia']}
Review Text: Meh. The woman is trying to explain to them that the "pipe" or "bridge" is just a lava tube or molten rock formation (The moon used to be part of the earth) but they are ignoring her. This is bad documentary film making. They are literally just speaking over her with their own interpretations. Why even bother bringing in an expert to look?
Review Title: This is bad documentary film making
Rating: 2.0
--------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
The After Science Fiction ['A new Amazon Original Series: From Chris Carter, creator of The X-Files. Eight strangers are thrown together by mysterious forces and must help each other survive in a violent world that defies explanation. More episodes coming soon exclusively on Prime Instant Video.'] {'Subtitles': ['None available'], 'Directors': ['Chris Carter'], 'Producers': ['Chris Carter', 'Marc Rosen', 'Gabe Rotter'], 'Starring': ['Aldis Hodge', 'Andrew Howard', 'Arielle Kebbel']} I really wanted to like this. But this isn't a show so much as a series of somewhat related scenes.

A rather attractive woman gets nude after IT happens (whatever IT is)...so if that's your thing, at least there's that. To be clear...the girl skinny dips in front of strangers after IT happens because....ratings?

I guess ratings are immaterial here. But it's just a very strange thing to shoe-horn into a show about the end of the world.

Anyway, cliches ahoy, matey! I think we pretty much have every modern stereotype covered here, and it's all terribly boring.

This show is like The Walking Dead with a much smaller budget, worse actors, a much smaller budget and a terrible script.

If you do watch it, consider it a comedy going in and you might enjoy it. I really wanted to like this. This critical approach underscores the significance of expert voices in narratives, as seen in their latest interaction regarding a documentary that they found lacking in effective storytelling.

Their thoughtful evaluation process reveals a pattern of acknowledging both strengths and weaknesses while appreciating diverse interpretations. This recent interaction further emphasizes their intent to engage with complex narratives and the essential role of expert insight in shaping discourse.
